channel.title: Pascal
channel.description:
Well PasCal is a programming languge incase you did'nt know, lol. "designed in 1968/9 and published in 1970 by Niklaus Wirth as a small and efficient language intended to encourage good programming practices using structured programming and data structuring."
[code] Program HelloWorld(output); begin writeLn('Hello, World!') end. [/code]
[b]Data types[/b]
[code]type byte = 0..255; signedbyte = -128..127; string = packed array [1..255] of char;[/code]
Discuss;

item.title: Pascal
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:6, topic:293665”]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Lisp

I Win

[code]
(defmacro until (test &body body)
`(do ()
(,test)
,@body))

;; example
(until (= (random 10) 0)
(write-line “Hello”))
[/code][/quote]

Confusions, but looks interesting.

Read full topic

item.title: Pascal
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Lisp

I Win

 (defmacro until (test &body body)
   `(do ()
        (,test)
      ,@body))
 
 ;; example
 (until (= (random 10) 0) 
   (write-line "Hello"))

item.title: Pascal
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

[quote=“Kihomura, post:2, topic:293665”][quote] * “She saw three men: Donald, who came from New Zealand; John, the milkman’s son; and George, a gaunt kind of man.”
* “Several fast food restaurants can be found in each of London, England; Paris, France; Dublin, Ireland; and Madrid, Spain.”
* “Examples of familiar sequences are: one, two, and three; a, b, and c; and first, second, and third.”[/quote]

Learn to use a semicolon.[/quote]

l2stick to the topic titles.

item.title: Pascal
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

Well PasCal is a programming languge incase you did’nt know, lol.
“designed in 1968/9 and published in 1970 by Niklaus Wirth as a small and efficient language intended to encourage good programming practices using structured programming and data structuring.”

Program HelloWorld(output);
begin
  writeLn('Hello, World!')
end.

Data types

type byte = 0..255; signedbyte = -128..127; string = packed array [1..255] of char;

Discuss;
